title: Falling Awake (poetry collection)
text:
Falling Awake is a 2016 <a href="poetry">poetry</a> collection by <a href="English%20people">English</a> poet <a href="Alice%20Oswald">Alice Oswald</a>, published by <a href="Jonathan%20Cape">Jonathan Cape</a>. Her seventh book of poetry, it won the 2016 <a href="Costa%20Book%20Awards">Costa Poetry Award</a> and the 2017 <a href="Griffin%20Poetry%20Prize">Griffin Poetry Prize</a>.
The poems explore <a href="Theme%20%28narrative%29">themes</a> relating to <a href="nature">nature</a>, <a href="mutability">mutability</a>, cycles and rebirth, as well as <a href="myth">myth</a>ology. The final poem in the collection, <a href="Tithonus">Tithonus</a> (46 Minutes in the Life of the Dawn), is meant to be experienced over the course of 46 minutes as when Oswald performs it live, the amount of time between pitch-darkness and dawn on a typical <a href="midsummer">midsummer</a> morning in her native <a href="Devon">Devon</a>.
The book was met with critical acclaim upon release.
Critical Reception.
Upon its release, Falling Awake was met with widespread critical acclaim in a variety of publications, including <a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>, <a href="The%20New%20Yorker">The New Yorker</a>, and <a href="The%20London%20Magazine">The London Magazine</a>.
Writing in The Guardian, <a href="Kate%20Kellaway">Kate Kellaway</a> described it as "an astonishing book of beauty, intensity and poise – a revelation."
<a href="Jeremy%20Noel-Tod">Jeremy Noel-Tod</a> wrote that ""Falling Awake" "glittering in the gaps between things" confirms [Oswald] as one of the most gifted English poets of the past 20 years" in <a href="The%20Sunday%20Times">The Sunday Times</a>.
